prompt: <description>**Part 1: Construct a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top and bottom.** Start by creating a new coordinate system. Set the Euler Angles to [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] and the Translation Vector to [0.0, 0.5, 0.0]. This will ensure the top and bottom faces of the prism are parallel to each other, and the front and back faces are perpendicular to the top and bottom faces. The prism is also centered on the origin. For the sketch, create a new face on the XY plane of the coordinate system. Create a loop on this face with six lines: 1. Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.75, 0.0] 2. Line 2: Start Point [0.75, 0.0], End Point [0.75, 0.125] 3. Line 3: Start Point [0.75, 0.125], End Point [0.25, 0.125] 4. Line 4: Start Point [0.25, 0.125], End Point [0.25, 0.5] 5. Line 5: Start Point [0.25, 0.5], End Point [0.0, 0.5] 6. Line 6: Start Point [0.0, 0.5], End Point [0.0, 0.0] After creating the external loop, you’ll have a 2D sketch resembling the shape of a slightly tapered rectangle. To transform the 2D sketch into a 3D model, set the sketch_scale to 0.75. Scale the sketch using this factor. Extrude the sketch by 0.5 units in the direction of the positive Z-axis. This will create a 3D model of a rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top and bottom. **Part 2: Construct a smaller three-dimensional rectangular prism on top of the first one, with a gap between them.** Start by creating a new coordinate system on the side of the first part. Set the Euler Angles to [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and the Translation Vector to [0.25, 0.375, 0.125]. This will position the new part on top of the first one with a small gap between them. For the sketch, create a new face on the XY plane of the coordinate system. Create a loop on this face with four lines: 1. Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.5, 0.0] 2. Line 2: Start Point [0.5, 0.0], End Point [0.5, 0.125] 3. Line 3: Start Point [0.5, 0.125], End Point [0.0, 0.125] 4. Line 4: Start Point [0.0, 0.125], End Point [0.0, 0.0] After creating the external loop, you’ll have a 2D sketch resembling the shape of a smaller rectangular prism. To transform the 2D sketch into a 3D model, set the sketch_scale to 0.5. Scale the sketch using this factor. Extrude the sketch by 0.25 units in the direction of the positive Z-axis. This will create a second 3D rectangular prism on top of the first one with a gap between them. Review and verify that each part's dimensions, shapes, and relative positions match the specified descriptions. Adjust the curves, loops, and faces accordingly. The final CAD model should resemble a slightly tapered rectangular prism with another smaller tapered rectangular prism sitting on top, separated by a small gap.</description>
